moves.2. exd5 Nf6 3. Bc4: ...that in this case (the only one I know) can't be followed by the Icelandic gambit, since after the exchanges black will have an isolani on the e column... not any good!
moves.3... Nxd5: So this is the profilactic move. But I am on almost unexplored threads.
moves.4. Qf3: Classic opening trick. It is either a naive attack or a nasty trick I should know.
moves.4... e6: Cautiosly, and blocking in my lsb (which is the beginning of my disgrace...
moves.5. d3 Nc6: N looks as if to threat c7, but if fact he is aiming to e5, forking Q and B and resolving the tension in the center.
moves.6. c3: White, as foreseen, must defend c7 against the knight's jumps, so I go...
moves.6... Ne5 7. Bxd5: White reacts, and it seems a blunder. Now, I can take with the queen and the game is even. Or I can...
moves.7... Nxf3+ 8. Bxf3 Qxd3: I am +4, and it seems I am winning.
moves.9. Be3 Qc2: I wonder how can white defend b7 and develop, but I was dead wrong.
moves.10. Nd2 Qxb2 11. Rb1 Qxc3: +6. A N pinned. Relatively safe Q. b2 is lost, but I would welcome to exchange one of white's bishops. It is starting to look hard for me to develop.
moves.12. Ne2 Qa5 13. O-O: I though about Bb4 here, but Nc4 was awaiting me. Qxa7 would have been to insist on the classical "too greedy" mistake I was already in.
moves.13... c6: Guarding b2. I have to solidify, but in doing so, I wasn't answering the question "where to develop my lsb? How to bring the rooks into the game? How bitter feel all those pawns.
moves.14. Nc4 Qa6 15. Rfc1: Can you believe it? I am under heavy fire! My opponent well could have sacrified the Queen on purpose! I hunger for good moves.
moves.15... Be7 16. a3 O-O 17. Bd4 Bd7: +6 and I should think about f6-e5 to win some manouver space.
moves.19. Be3: White is too wise for that.
moves.19... Be8: f6 was coming into consideration, but I wasn't sure at all about opening the game. I needed control.
moves.20. h3: Ok, white will get me by hunger, with waiting moves until I lose my temper. Which I am very willing to do, in spite of a counter unbalanced exchange that can rid off some of white's overwhelmigly well placed pieces.
moves.21... Bxc1 22. Rxa6 Rd1+: Just to win a tempo for doubling rooks.
moves.23. Kh2 bxa6: Sad necessity. I will lose a minor piece, leaving him the bishop's pair. But at least I had some mobility with my two rooks.
moves.24. Nxc1 Re1: ? Blunder. Bd7 and I will have to work hard to even save the R from an exchange.
moves.25. Nc4 Rb8 26. Nd3: I am dangerously driving his pieces to open field, knowing that minor piece's weakness against the rooks it the "two undefended sided pieces" situation.
moves.26... Ra1 27. Bxa7 Rbb1: Now is where, if white plays as I suppose, I'll get him in a sided undefended situation.
moves.28. Bd4 Ra4: That's it. Of course, white has the other knight, so...
moves.29. Ndb2: Now, I will lose a rook for two minor pieces. I am +4 now, I will be +6 then, but I will lose some of the lonely pawns on the kingside. I can hope just to be an exchange and a pawn up. And with the feeling to have fooled a horrible death.
moves.29... Rxb2: Now, of course white should have taken with the bishop, keeping the pair, but...
moves.30. Nxb2: A blunder, since in such a position the bishop pair is most valuable.
moves.30... Rxd4: Now the game, sadly, loses interest, but it is still an unbalanced game...
moves.31. Kg3 g5: I can play c4, of course, but I liked to speculate on the king itself.
moves.32. Bh5 Kg7 33. Nd1 Kh6 34. Bf3 f5 35. K: Nasty threat, but all is under control.
moves.36... Kg6: Bh5+ doesn't work because there is no check fork on Nxf5.
moves.37. g4 Rf4: ...wanting to play risky. All went as predicted:
moves.38. gxf5+ Kf6 39. Bg4 Rxf2+ 40. Kg1: ...and here my opponent abandoned the game. My queen pawns will cost white a piece each, and then, my rook will win.

gameName: I'm up and I can't feel it...
